chunk_title: Description of the Associated Loan, BH-L1041
chunk: This Technical Cooperation (TC) will support the implementation of the Bahamas Airport Infrastructure Program (BH-L1041; 3907/OC-BH), with the overarching goal of contributing to the regional and global sustainable integration of The Bahamas through enhancements to secure air transport infrastructure in the Family Islands (FI). The program, structured as a GOM, aims to strengthen The Bahamas’ connectivity with the Caribbean and the wider world by improving air travel efficiency and accessibility for both residents and visitors. This will be achieved through infrastructure upgrades—including the rehabilitation and maintenance of four Family Island airports (Exuma, North Eleuthera, Marsh Harbour, and Treasure Cay)—to ensure compliance with international aviation standards, with consideration for climate resilience and sustainability. This loan, of US$35,000,000 from Ordinary Capital and US$18,800,000 from the counterpart, totaling US$53,800,000, is currently active and disbursing.

chunk_title: Description of the Associated Loan, BH-L1041
chunk:
The  ongoing  airport  infrastructure  program  includes  two  components,  i)  Civil  Works 
and  Equipment,  and  ii)  Implementation  Support  and  Institutional  Strengthening, 
Component  one  finances  investments  needed  to  upgrade  the  infrastructure  and 
equipment of the four selected Family Island airports. To meet projected traffic, comply 
with International Civil Aviation (ICAO) standards, and increase the climate resilience 
of the airports, the component includes the upgrading and rehabilitation of the airport 
runways,  taxiways,  parking  aprons  and  meteorological  equipment,  runway  lights, 
markings, and fencing. It also incorporates terminal works to equip the airports with 
infrastructure  capable  of  handling  increasing  passengers  while  providing  energy 
efficiency  and  climate  resilience.  Equipment  also  includes  Rescue  and  Firefighting 
(RFF) vehicles and X-ray machines for passenger terminals.

chunk_title: Description of the Associated Loan, BH-L1041
chunk:
The second component supports capacity-building for the Ministry of Works and the 
Ministry  of  Tourism  and  Aviation  (MTA),  related  to  contract  management,  technical-
environmental audits, monitoring and evaluations, and completion reports. It will also 
provide climate change training for MOW staff and technical and legal work needed to 
prepare a management contract once the construction phase ends.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
The  objective  of  this  Technical  Cooperation  is  to  provide  support  for  sustainable 
aviation in The Bahamas including the development of a sustainable aviation strategy, 
studies  to  support  the  adoption  of  sustainable  aviation  fuels,  the  design  of  green, 
climate  resilient  and  energy  efficient  aerodromes,  and  programs  that  promote  labor 
force development, human capacity building and social inclusion in the aviation sector.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk: The  Technical  Cooperation  is  expected  to  deliver  direct  and  indirect  economic  and social benefits for the entire country and to the aviation sector. The main beneficiaries of  the  TC  will  be  the  Ministry  of  Tourism,  Investment  and  Aviation  (MoTIA)  and  the Ministry of Works and Family Island Affairs MoW&FIA.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk: The aviation sector is critical to regional integration in The Bahamas. An archipelagic country, consisting of 700 islands spread over 100,000 square miles of ocean, the population of over 400,000 is primarily (70.4%) concentrated on the island of New Providence, while approximately 15% of residents are located on Grand Bahama, with the remainder of the population spread across the other 28 Family Islands. Moreover, the remoteness of the Family Islands (FI) and their long distances to the major population centers means local Bahamians residing outside of New Providence and Grand Bahama are highly dependent on accessible, reliable and frequent modes of air transport for both domestic and international travel.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
Additionally,  tourism  provides  a  significant  contribution  to  the  Bahamian  economy  – 
approximately 50% of GDP (nearly $3 billion in GDP). In 2024, The Bahamas received 
11.22 million international visitors, with approximately 85% arriving by sea and 15% 
by air. While cruise visitors typically stay for less than a day, tourists arriving by air, or 
stopover  tourists,  contribute  significantly  to  the  local  economy  through  longer  stays 
averaging 4 to 6 nights. International air passenger arrivals to The Bahamas grew by 
17% in 2023, reaching 1,719,980 visitors, up from 1,470,244 in 2022.1 This marked a 
significant  rebound  from  the  pandemic  and  record-setting  year  for  the  country's tourism sector. Thus, the effective and efficient functioning of air transport systems is 
critical to sustaining long-term economic growth of the country.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
Climate  Change:  International  aviation  currently  contributes  approximately  2.5%  of 
global CO₂ emissions, up from 2.3% in 2000, and this share is expected to rise due to 
the continued expansion of air transport worldwide2. Recognizing the sector’s growing 
environmental impact, the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), has 
adopted  a  set  of  global  aspirational  goals  aimed  at  mitigating  aviation’s  carbon 
footprint. These include a 2% annual improvement in fuel efficiency and a commitment 
to  cap  net  carbon  emissions  at  2020  levels,  despite  projected  growth  in  air  traffic. 
These targets underscore the urgent need for countries like The Bahamas, which are 
highly vulnerable to climate change and heavily reliant on aviation for connectivity and 
economic development, to pursue sustainable, inclusive, and climate-resilient aviation 
strategies.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
In addition, The Bahamas is highly exposed to climate change, including hurricanes 
and to seasonal tropical storms. Over the last 45 years the country has been hit by 12 
major hurricanes that have caused loss of lives, damage to quality of life and economic 
stress. For example, the impact of hurricane Dorian (August 2019) was estimated at 
US$3.4  billion3.  Sustainability  and  climate-change  resilience  among  all  forms  of 
transportation  (aviation  included)  is  a  priority  for  The  Bahamas  due  to  previous 
episodes  of  extreme  weather  events  and the  high  probability  of  future  disruption. 
Moreover,  air  connectivity  and  climate  resilience  in  The  Bahamas  is  also  critical  to 
Disaster  Risk  Management.  As  an  archipelagic  nation,  the  Bahamas  air  transport 
sector is critical to ensuring rapid response and recovery during emergencies, serving 
as  a  lifeline  for  inter-island  connectivity.  Airports  often  become  critical  hubs  for  the 
delivery  of  humanitarian  aid,  medical  supplies,  and  emergency  personnel,  and  are 
essential  for  the  evacuation  of  vulnerable  populations.4  Strengthening  the  aviation 
sector’s  resilience  and  operational  capacity  is  therefore  fundamental  to  enhancing 
national  disaster  preparedness  and  response,  safeguarding  lives,  and  maintaining 
continuity of essential services across the archipelago.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
The  Government  of  The  Bahamas  is  committed  to  advancing  climate  resilience, 
sustainability, gender inclusion, and institutional capacity within the aviation sector. To 
achieve this, the TC will support the development of a comprehensive Sustainable and 
Inclusive Aviation Strategy for The Bahamas that will establish a framework for green, 
low carbon, climate change resilient, and energy efficient and inclusive aerodromes. 
Moreover, the strategy will aim to promote gender equity through grants for women in 
aviation, enhance opportunities for persons with disabilities PwDs in aviation careers, 
and  expand  aviation  cadet  training  programs  to  engage  and  prepare  the  next 
generation of industry professionals. Additionally, the strategy will explore pathways 
for integrating sustainable aviation fuels, aligning with global efforts to reduce carbon 
emissions in the sector.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
Furthermore,  the  TC  will  support  the  effective  and  efficient  implementation  of  the 
Bahamas Airport Infrastructure Program (BH-L1041), program. This technical support 
will  be  critical  in  advancing  key  infrastructure  projects  that  will  improve  airport 
operations and connectivity across The Bahamas. Finally, it will also support training 
programs  that  will  enhance  the  capacity  of  stakeholders  involved  in  aviation  sector 
governance,  project  execution,  and  strategic planning,  starting  with  the  Ministry  of Tourism, Investment and Aviation (MoTIA). Strengthening institutional knowledge and 
expertise will ensure the long-term sustainability and success of these efforts.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
chunk:
The  TC  considers  six  consultancy  services,  four  of  which  will  be  carried  out  as 
corporate procurement services and two as individual consultancies. The consultancy 
services span the years 2026 and 2027. The earliest consultancy services will start in 
January 2026, following a hiring process conducted in November 2025. Therefore, the 
TC resources should be available by the start of November 2025 to avoid delays in 
the execution.
